evals.input: @perplexity-api who are the founders of raycast

search.content:
The founders of Raycast are **Thomas Mann** and **Petr Nikolaev**. Raycast is a productivity tool designed to help engineering teams streamline non-coding tasks, such as managing workflows in apps like Jira, GitHub, or Slack. The company was founded in 2020 and is based in London, UK.

- **Thomas Mann** is a founder of Raycast. He previously worked as a software engineer at companies like Facebook, Audi, ProSieben, and the Fraunhofer Society. Mann is involved in crafting Raycast and is also an author and contributor of Raycast extensions[1][2].

- **Petr Nikolaev** serves as the Co-Founder and CTO of Raycast. He is also an author and contributor of Raycast extensions. Nikolaev joined Raycast in April 2021 and is based in London[3].

# Stock Market Dynamics on February 26, 2025: A Comprehensive Analysis of Mixed Signals and Economic Uncertainties  

The U.S. stock market on February 26, 2025, presented a complex tableau of resilience and vulnerability as major indices diverged amid conflicting economic signals. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) eked out gains fueled by defensive sector rotations, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite extended their losing streaks to four sessions amid deteriorating consumer sentiment and geopolitical trade tensions[1][2][5]. Technology stocks bore the brunt of selling pressure ahead of NVIDIA’s pivotal earnings report[3][6], while energy shares slumped alongside oil prices as fears over demand destruction intensified[3][9]. Bond markets rallied sharply as investors sought refuge in Treasuries, driving benchmark yields to multi-month lows[3][9]. This report dissects the day’s developments across equities, fixed income, commodities, and policy landscapes while evaluating implications for near-term market trajectories.

## Major Indices Exhibit Divergent Performances  

### Dow Jones Industrial Average Bucks Bearish Trend  
The DJIA rose 0.4% (159.95 points) to close at 43,621.16—its strongest daily gain since February 13—as components like Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) stabilized despite broader financial sector anxieties[1][2]. This resilience reflected rotational buying into value-oriented industrials and consumer staples rather than broad-market conviction[2][6]. The index’s price-weighted structure amplified contributions from high-priced stocks less exposed to rate-sensitive growth narratives[5].  

### S&P 500 Extends Losses Amid Sector Fragmentation  
The S&P 500 declined 0.5% (28 points) to 5,955.25, with six of eleven sectors finishing negative[1][2]. Communication services (-1.8%) and technology (-1.3%) led declines as megacaps faced profit-taking ahead of NVIDIA’s earnings[3][6]. Conversely, defensive sectors like real estate (+1.4%) and consumer staples (+1.9%) outperformed as investors prioritized dividend stability amid recessionary whispers[2][9]. The index’s four-day slide marked its longest losing streak since September 2024[1], underscoring eroding risk appetite despite the DJIA’s anomalous strength[5].  

### Nasdaq Composite Enters Correction Territory  
The tech-heavy Nasdaq plummeted 1.4% (260.54 points) to 19,026.29—its lowest close since January 2025—as Tesla (TSLA) cratered 8.4% following production guidance cuts and Palantir (PLTR) slid 3.1% on AI monetization concerns[1][3][6]. Semiconductor stocks faced acute pressure ahead of NVIDIA’s after-hours earnings; the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (SOX) dropped 2.7% intraday before paring losses[3][10]. With advancing issues outnumbered nearly 2:1 by decliners[2], the index’s technical breakdown below its 50-day moving average signaled potential further downside absent immediate catalysts[8].

## Macroeconomic Headwinds Drive Risk-Off Sentiment  

### Consumer Confidence Collapse Spurs Recession Fears  
The Conference Board’s Consumer Confidence Index plunged to 98.3 in February—far below consensus estimates of 102.3—marking its lowest reading since August 2021 and third consecutive monthly decline[1][2][6]. Subcomponents revealed heightened inflation expectations (12-month CPI projections rose to 5.7%) alongside deteriorating labor market assessments[2][9]. This data followed weak retail sales and industrial production figures earlier in February, cementing Q1 GDP growth fears below 1% annualized[3][9].  

### Trump Administration’s Trade Policy Uncertainty Weighs  
President Trump’s announcement of impending 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports—coupled with directives to explore levies on Chinese copper—ignited stagflationary concerns across cyclical sectors[3][6]. Energy stocks slumped as WTI crude tumbled 2.5% to $69/barrel—a year-to-date low—on fears that protectionism would suppress global trade volumes[3][9]. Industrials like Caterpillar (CAT) slid 1.8% on supply chain disruption risks[2], while automaker Stellantis (STLA) plummeted post-earnings amid warnings of tariff-driven margin compression[10].

### Treasury Rally Accelerates Amid Flight to Quality  
The benchmark 10-year yield plunged 14 basis points to 4.28%—its lowest since December 2024—as weak consumer data amplified bets on Fed dovishness[3][9]. Two-year yields fell below Fed Funds futures-implied terminal rates for Q4-2025 (~4%), reflecting growing expectations for accelerated rate cuts starting June[9]. Demand surged at a $62B five-year note auction (bid-to-cover ratio: 2.54), underscoring institutional appetite for duration risk amid equity volatility[9][12].

Investment-grade corporate bond spreads edged out +5bps to +127bps as HYG ETF outflows hit $890M—the largest daily redemption since October-2024[12]. However, limited distress in leveraged loan markets suggested systemic liquidity remains robust despite equity turbulence[12].
